Original Text: HE HOPED THERE WOULD BE STEW FOR DINNER TURNIPS AND CARROTS AND BRUISED POTATOES AND FAT MUTTON PIECES TO BE LADLED OUT IN THICK PEPPERED FLOUR FATTENED SAUCE
Transcribed Text: He hoped there would be stew for dinner, turnips and carrots and bruised potatoes and fat mutton pieces to be ladled out in thick, peppered, flour-fattened sauce.

Original Text: STUFF IT INTO YOU HIS BELLY COUNSELLED HIM
Transcribed Text: Stuff it into you, his belly counseled him.

Original Text: AFTER EARLY NIGHTFALL THE YELLOW LAMPS WOULD LIGHT UP HERE AND THERE THE SQUALID QUARTER OF THE BROTHELS
Transcribed Text: after early nightfall the yellow lamps would light up here and there the squalid quarter of the brothels

Original Text: HELLO BERTIE ANY GOOD IN YOUR MIND
Transcribed Text: "'Hello, Bertie. Any good in your mind?'

Original Text: NUMBER TEN FRESH NELLY IS WAITING ON YOU GOOD NIGHT HUSBAND
Transcribed Text: Number 10. Fresh Nelly is waiting on you.  Good night, husband.

Original Text: THE MUSIC CAME NEARER AND HE RECALLED THE WORDS THE WORDS OF SHELLEY'S FRAGMENT UPON THE MOON WANDERING COMPANIONLESS PALE FOR WEARINESS
Transcribed Text: the music came nearer and he recalled the words the words of shelley's fragment upon the moon wandering companionless pale for weariness

Original Text: THE DULL LIGHT FELL MORE FAINTLY UPON THE PAGE WHEREON ANOTHER EQUATION BEGAN TO UNFOLD ITSELF SLOWLY AND TO SPREAD ABROAD ITS WIDENING TAIL
Transcribed Text: the dull light fell more faintly upon the page whereon another equation began to unfold itself slowly and to spread abroad its widening tail

Original Text: A COLD LUCID INDIFFERENCE REIGNED IN HIS SOUL
Transcribed Text: A cold, lucid indifference reigned in his soul.

Original Text: THE CHAOS IN WHICH HIS ARDOUR EXTINGUISHED ITSELF WAS A COLD INDIFFERENT KNOWLEDGE OF HIMSELF
Transcribed Text: The chaos in which his ardor extinguished itself was a cold, indifferent knowledge of himself.

Original Text: AT MOST BY AN ALMS GIVEN TO A BEGGAR WHOSE BLESSING HE FLED FROM HE MIGHT HOPE WEARILY TO WIN FOR HIMSELF SOME MEASURE OF ACTUAL GRACE
Transcribed Text: At most, by an alms given to a beggar whose blessing he fled from, he might hope wearily to win for himself some measure of actual grace.

Original Text: WELL NOW ENNIS I DECLARE YOU HAVE A HEAD AND SO HAS MY STICK
Transcribed Text: "'Well now, Ennis, I declare you have a head, and so has my stick.'

Original Text: ON SATURDAY MORNINGS WHEN THE SODALITY MET IN THE CHAPEL TO RECITE THE LITTLE OFFICE HIS PLACE WAS A CUSHIONED KNEELING DESK AT THE RIGHT OF THE ALTAR FROM WHICH HE LED HIS WING OF BOYS THROUGH THE RESPONSES
Transcribed Text: on saturday mornings when the sodality met in the chapel to recite the little office his place was a cushioned kneeling desk at the right of the altar from which he led his wing of boys through the responses

Original Text: HER EYES SEEMED TO REGARD HIM WITH MILD PITY HER HOLINESS A STRANGE LIGHT GLOWING FAINTLY UPON HER FRAIL FLESH DID NOT HUMILIATE THE SINNER WHO APPROACHED HER
Transcribed Text: her eyes seemed to regard him with mild pity her holiness a strange light glowing faintly upon her frail flesh did not humiliate the sinner who approached her

Original Text: IF EVER HE WAS IMPELLED TO CAST SIN FROM HIM AND TO REPENT THE IMPULSE THAT MOVED HIM WAS THE WISH TO BE HER KNIGHT
Transcribed Text: if ever he was impelled to cast sin from him and to repent the impulse that moved him was the wish to be her knight

Original Text: HE TRIED TO THINK HOW IT COULD BE
Transcribed Text: He tried to think how it could be.

Original Text: BUT THE DUSK DEEPENING IN THE SCHOOLROOM COVERED OVER HIS THOUGHTS THE BELL RANG
Transcribed Text: but the dusk, deepening in the schoolroom, covered over his thoughts.  The bell rang.

Original Text: THEN YOU CAN ASK HIM QUESTIONS ON THE CATECHISM DEDALUS
Transcribed Text: Then you can ask him questions on the catechism, Daedalus.

Original Text: STEPHEN LEANING BACK AND DRAWING IDLY ON HIS SCRIBBLER LISTENED TO THE TALK ABOUT HIM WHICH HERON CHECKED FROM TIME TO TIME BY SAYING
Transcribed Text: Stephen, leaning back and drawing idly on his scribbler,  listened to the talk about him which Heron checked from time to time by saying,

Original Text: IT WAS STRANGE TOO THAT HE FOUND AN ARID PLEASURE IN FOLLOWING UP TO THE END THE RIGID LINES OF THE DOCTRINES OF THE CHURCH AND PENETRATING INTO OBSCURE SILENCES ONLY TO HEAR AND FEEL THE MORE DEEPLY HIS OWN CONDEMNATION
Transcribed Text: it was strange too that he found an arid pleasure in following up to the end the rigid lines of the doctrines of the church and penetrating into obscure silences only to hear and feel the more deeply his own condemnation

Original Text: THE SENTENCE OF SAINT JAMES WHICH SAYS THAT HE WHO OFFENDS AGAINST ONE COMMANDMENT BECOMES GUILTY OF ALL HAD SEEMED TO HIM FIRST A SWOLLEN PHRASE UNTIL HE HAD BEGUN TO GROPE IN THE DARKNESS OF HIS OWN STATE
Transcribed Text: The sentence of St. James, which says that he who offends against one commandment becomes guilty of all, had seemed to him first a swollen phrase, until he had begun to grope in the darkness of his own state.

Original Text: IF A MAN HAD STOLEN A POUND IN HIS YOUTH AND HAD USED THAT POUND TO AMASS A HUGE FORTUNE HOW MUCH WAS HE OBLIGED TO GIVE BACK THE POUND HE HAD STOLEN ONLY OR THE POUND TOGETHER WITH THE COMPOUND INTEREST ACCRUING UPON IT OR ALL HIS HUGE FORTUNE
Transcribed Text: if a man had stolen a pound in his youth and had used that pound to amass a huge fortune how much was he obliged to give back the pound he had stolen only or the pound together with the compound interest accruing upon it or all his huge fortune

Original Text: IF A LAYMAN IN GIVING BAPTISM POUR THE WATER BEFORE SAYING THE WORDS IS THE CHILD BAPTIZED
Transcribed Text: If a layman, in giving baptism, pour the water before saying the words,  Is the child baptized?

Original Text: HOW COMES IT THAT WHILE THE FIRST BEATITUDE PROMISES THE KINGDOM OF HEAVEN TO THE POOR OF HEART THE SECOND BEATITUDE PROMISES ALSO TO THE MEEK THAT THEY SHALL POSSESS THE LAND
Transcribed Text: How comes it that while the first beatitude promises the kingdom of heaven to the poor of heart,  the second beatitude promises also to the meek that they shall possess the land?

Original Text: WHY WAS THE SACRAMENT OF THE EUCHARIST INSTITUTED UNDER THE TWO SPECIES OF BREAD AND WINE IF JESUS CHRIST BE PRESENT BODY AND BLOOD SOUL AND DIVINITY IN THE BREAD ALONE AND IN THE WINE ALONE
Transcribed Text: why was the sacrament of the eucharist instituted under the two species of bread and wine if jesus christ be present body and blood soul and divinity in the bread alone and in the wine alone

Original Text: IF THE WINE CHANGE INTO VINEGAR AND THE HOST CRUMBLE INTO CORRUPTION AFTER THEY HAVE BEEN CONSECRATED IS JESUS CHRIST STILL PRESENT UNDER THEIR SPECIES AS GOD AND AS MAN
Transcribed Text: If the wine change into vinegar, and the host crumble into corruption after they have been consecrated,  is Jesus Christ still present under their species as God and as man?

Original Text: A GENTLE KICK FROM THE TALL BOY IN THE BENCH BEHIND URGED STEPHEN TO ASK A DIFFICULT QUESTION
Transcribed Text: A gentle kick from the tall boy in the bench behind urged Stephen to ask a difficult question.

Original Text: THE RECTOR DID NOT ASK FOR A CATECHISM TO HEAR THE LESSON FROM
Transcribed Text: the rector did not ask for a catechism to hear the lesson from

Original Text: HE CLASPED HIS HANDS ON THE DESK AND SAID
Transcribed Text: He clasped his hands on the desk and said,

Original Text: THE RETREAT WILL BEGIN ON WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON IN HONOUR OF SAINT FRANCIS XAVIER WHOSE FEAST DAY IS SATURDAY
Transcribed Text: The retreat will begin on Wednesday afternoon in honor of St. Francis Xavier, whose feast day is Saturday.

Original Text: ON FRIDAY CONFESSION WILL BE HEARD ALL THE AFTERNOON AFTER BEADS
Transcribed Text: On Friday, confession will be heard all the afternoon after beads.

Original Text: BEWARE OF MAKING THAT MISTAKE
Transcribed Text: Beware of making that mistake.

Original Text: STEPHEN'S HEART BEGAN SLOWLY TO FOLD AND FADE WITH FEAR LIKE A WITHERING FLOWER
Transcribed Text: Stephen's heart began slowly to fold and fade with fear like a withering flower.

Original Text: HE IS CALLED AS YOU KNOW THE APOSTLE OF THE INDIES
Transcribed Text: He is called, as you know, the Apostle of the Indies.

Original Text: A GREAT SAINT SAINT FRANCIS XAVIER
Transcribed Text: A great saint, St. Francis Xavier.

Original Text: THE RECTOR PAUSED AND THEN SHAKING HIS CLASPED HANDS BEFORE HIM WENT ON
Transcribed Text: The rector paused, and then, shaking his clasped hands before him, went on.

Original Text: HE HAD THE FAITH IN HIM THAT MOVES MOUNTAINS
Transcribed Text: He had the faith in him that moves mountains.

Original Text: A GREAT SAINT SAINT FRANCIS XAVIER
Transcribed Text: a great saint Saint Francis Xavier

Original Text: IN THE SILENCE THEIR DARK FIRE KINDLED THE DUSK INTO A TAWNY GLOW
Transcribed Text: In the silence their dark fire kindled the dusk into a tawny glow.

Original Text: HE COULD WAIT NO LONGER
Transcribed Text: He could wait no longer.

Original Text: FOR A FULL HOUR HE HAD PACED UP AND DOWN WAITING BUT HE COULD WAIT NO LONGER
Transcribed Text: For a full hour he had paced up and down, waiting, but he could wait no longer.

Original Text: HE SET OFF ABRUPTLY FOR THE BULL WALKING RAPIDLY LEST HIS FATHER'S SHRILL WHISTLE MIGHT CALL HIM BACK AND IN A FEW MOMENTS HE HAD ROUNDED THE CURVE AT THE POLICE BARRACK AND WAS SAFE
Transcribed Text: He set off abruptly for the bull, walking rapidly lest his father's shrill whistle might call him back,  and in a few moments he had rounded the curve at the police barrack and was safe.

Original Text: THE UNIVERSITY
Transcribed Text: The University.

Original Text: PRIDE AFTER SATISFACTION UPLIFTED HIM LIKE LONG SLOW WAVES
Transcribed Text: Pride after satisfaction uplifted him like long, slow waves.

Original Text: WHOSE FEET ARE AS THE FEET OF HARTS AND UNDERNEATH THE EVERLASTING ARMS
Transcribed Text: whose feet are as the feet of hearts and underneath the everlasting arms.

Original Text: THE PRIDE OF THAT DIM IMAGE BROUGHT BACK TO HIS MIND THE DIGNITY OF THE OFFICE HE HAD REFUSED
Transcribed Text: The pride of that dim image brought back to his mind the dignity of the office he had refused.

Original Text: SOON THE WHOLE BRIDGE WAS TREMBLING AND RESOUNDING
Transcribed Text: Soon the whole bridge was trembling and resounding.

Original Text: THE UNCOUTH FACES PASSED HIM TWO BY TWO STAINED YELLOW OR RED OR LIVID BY THE SEA AND AS HE STROVE TO LOOK AT THEM WITH EASE AND INDIFFERENCE A FAINT STAIN OF PERSONAL SHAME AND COMMISERATION ROSE TO HIS OWN FACE
Transcribed Text: the uncouth faces passed him two by two stained yellow or red or livid by the sea and as he strove to look at them with ease and indifference a faint stain of personal shame and commiseration rose to his own face

Original Text: ANGRY WITH HIMSELF HE TRIED TO HIDE HIS FACE FROM THEIR EYES BY GAZING DOWN SIDEWAYS INTO THE SHALLOW SWIRLING WATER UNDER THE BRIDGE BUT HE STILL SAW A REFLECTION THEREIN OF THEIR TOP HEAVY SILK HATS AND HUMBLE TAPE LIKE COLLARS AND LOOSELY HANGING CLERICAL CLOTHES BROTHER HICKEY
Transcribed Text: Angry with himself, he tried to hide his face from their eyes by gazing down sideways into  the shallow, swirling water under the bridge, but he still saw a reflection therein of their  top-heavy silk hats, and humble, tape-like collars, and loosely hanging clerical clothes.  Brother Hickey!

Original Text: BROTHER MAC ARDLE BROTHER KEOGH
Transcribed Text: Brother McArdle.  Brother Kieff.

Original Text: THEIR PIETY WOULD BE LIKE THEIR NAMES LIKE THEIR FACES LIKE THEIR CLOTHES AND IT WAS IDLE FOR HIM TO TELL HIMSELF THAT THEIR HUMBLE AND CONTRITE HEARTS IT MIGHT BE PAID A FAR RICHER TRIBUTE OF DEVOTION THAN HIS HAD EVER BEEN A GIFT TENFOLD MORE ACCEPTABLE THAN HIS ELABORATE ADORATION
Transcribed Text: their piety would be like their names like their faces like their clothes and it was idle for him to tell himself that their humble and contrite hearts it might be paid a far richer tribute of devotion than his had ever been a gift tenfold more acceptable than his elaborate adoration

Original Text: IT WAS IDLE FOR HIM TO MOVE HIMSELF TO BE GENEROUS TOWARDS THEM TO TELL HIMSELF THAT IF HE EVER CAME TO THEIR GATES STRIPPED OF HIS PRIDE BEATEN AND IN BEGGAR'S WEEDS THAT THEY WOULD BE GENEROUS TOWARDS HIM LOVING HIM AS THEMSELVES
Transcribed Text: it was idle for him to move himself to be generous towards them to tell himself that if he ever came to their gates stripped of his pride beaten and in beggars weeds that they would be generous towards him loving him as themselves

Original Text: IDLE AND EMBITTERING FINALLY TO ARGUE AGAINST HIS OWN DISPASSIONATE CERTITUDE THAT THE COMMANDMENT OF LOVE BADE US NOT TO LOVE OUR NEIGHBOUR AS OURSELVES WITH THE SAME AMOUNT AND INTENSITY OF LOVE BUT TO LOVE HIM AS OURSELVES WITH THE SAME KIND OF LOVE
Transcribed Text: idle and embittering finally to argue against his own dispassionate certitude that the commandment of love bade us not to love our neighbor as ourselves with the same amount and intensity of love but to love him as ourselves with the same kind of love

Original Text: THE PHRASE AND THE DAY AND THE SCENE HARMONIZED IN A CHORD
Transcribed Text: The phrase and the day, and the scene, harmonized in accord.

Original Text: WORDS WAS IT THEIR COLOURS
Transcribed Text: Words.  Was it their colors?

Original Text: THEY WERE VOYAGING ACROSS THE DESERTS OF THE SKY A HOST OF NOMADS ON THE MARCH VOYAGING HIGH OVER IRELAND WESTWARD BOUND
Transcribed Text: They were voyaging across the deserts of the sky, a host of nomads on the march,  voyaging high over Ireland, westward bound.

Original Text: THE EUROPE THEY HAD COME FROM LAY OUT THERE BEYOND THE IRISH SEA EUROPE OF STRANGE TONGUES AND VALLEYED AND WOODBEGIRT AND CITADELLED AND OF ENTRENCHED AND MARSHALLED RACES
Transcribed Text: the europe they had come from lay out there beyond the irish sea europe of strange tongues and valleyed and wood begirt and citadeled and of entrenched and marshalled races

Original Text: AGAIN AGAIN
Transcribed Text: again, again.

Original Text: A VOICE FROM BEYOND THE WORLD WAS CALLING
Transcribed Text: A voice from beyond the world was calling.

Original Text: HELLO STEPHANOS HERE COMES THE DEDALUS
Transcribed Text: Hello, Stephanos. Here comes the Daedalus.

Original Text: THEIR DIVING STONE POISED ON ITS RUDE SUPPORTS AND ROCKING UNDER THEIR PLUNGES AND THE ROUGH HEWN STONES OF THE SLOPING BREAKWATER OVER WHICH THEY SCRAMBLED IN THEIR HORSEPLAY GLEAMED WITH COLD WET LUSTRE
Transcribed Text: their diving stone poised on its rude supports and rocking under their plunges and the rough-hewn stones of the sloping breakwater over which they scrambled in their horseplay gleamed with cold wet lustre

Original Text: HE STOOD STILL IN DEFERENCE TO THEIR CALLS AND PARRIED THEIR BANTER WITH EASY WORDS
Transcribed Text: He stood still in deference to their calls, and parried their banter with easy words.

Original Text: IT WAS A PAIN TO SEE THEM AND A SWORD LIKE PAIN TO SEE THE SIGNS OF ADOLESCENCE THAT MADE REPELLENT THEIR PITIABLE NAKEDNESS
Transcribed Text: It was a pain to see them, and a sword-like pain to see the signs of adolescence that made repellent their pitiable nakedness.

Original Text: STEPHANOS DEDALOS
Transcribed Text: Stephanos der Los

Original Text: A MOMENT BEFORE THE GHOST OF THE ANCIENT KINGDOM OF THE DANES HAD LOOKED FORTH THROUGH THE VESTURE OF THE HAZEWRAPPED CITY
Transcribed Text: A moment before, the ghost of the ancient kingdom of the Danes had looked forth through the vesture of the haze-wrapped city.

Original Text: YOU WILL FIND ME CONTINUALLY SPEAKING OF FOUR MEN TITIAN HOLBEIN TURNER AND TINTORET IN ALMOST THE SAME TERMS
Transcribed Text: you will find me continually speaking of four men titian holbein turner and tintoret in almost the same terms

Original Text: THEY UNITE EVERY QUALITY AND SOMETIMES YOU WILL FIND ME REFERRING TO THEM AS COLORISTS SOMETIMES AS CHIAROSCURISTS
Transcribed Text: They unite every quality, and sometimes you will find me referring to them as colorists,  sometimes as chiaroscurists.

Original Text: BY BEING STUDIOUS OF COLOR THEY ARE STUDIOUS OF DIVISION AND WHILE THE CHIAROSCURIST DEVOTES HIMSELF TO THE REPRESENTATION OF DEGREES OF FORCE IN ONE THING UNSEPARATED LIGHT THE COLORISTS HAVE FOR THEIR FUNCTION THE ATTAINMENT OF BEAUTY BY ARRANGEMENT OF THE DIVISIONS OF LIGHT
Transcribed Text: by being studious of colour they are studious of division and while the chiaroscurist devotes himself to the representation of degrees of force in one thing unseparated light the colourists have for their function the attainment of beauty by arrangement of the divisions of light

Original Text: MY FIRST AND PRINCIPAL REASON WAS THAT THEY ENFORCED BEYOND ALL RESISTANCE ON ANY STUDENT WHO MIGHT ATTEMPT TO COPY THEM THIS METHOD OF LAYING PORTIONS OF DISTINCT HUE SIDE BY SIDE
Transcribed Text: my first and principal reason was that they enforced beyond all resistance on any student who might attempt to copy them this method of laying portions of distinct hue side by side

Original Text: SOME OF THE TOUCHES INDEED WHEN THE TINT HAS BEEN MIXED WITH MUCH WATER HAVE BEEN LAID IN LITTLE DROPS OR PONDS SO THAT THE PIGMENT MIGHT CRYSTALLIZE HARD AT THE EDGE
Transcribed Text: some of the touches indeed when the tint has been mixed with much water have been laid in little drops or ponds so that the pigment might crystallize hard at the edge

Original Text: IT IS THE HEAD OF A PARROT WITH A LITTLE FLOWER IN HIS BEAK FROM A PICTURE OF CARPACCIO'S ONE OF HIS SERIES OF THE LIFE OF SAINT GEORGE
Transcribed Text: it is the head of a parrot with a little flower in his beak from a picture of carpaccio's one of his series of the life of st george

Original Text: THEN HE COMES TO THE BEAK OF IT
Transcribed Text: Then he comes to the beak of it.

Original Text: THE BROWN GROUND BENEATH IS LEFT FOR THE MOST PART ONE TOUCH OF BLACK IS PUT FOR THE HOLLOW TWO DELICATE LINES OF DARK GRAY DEFINE THE OUTER CURVE AND ONE LITTLE QUIVERING TOUCH OF WHITE DRAWS THE INNER EDGE OF THE MANDIBLE
Transcribed Text: the brown ground beneath is left for the most part one touch of black is put for the hollow two delicate lines of dark grey define the outer curve and one little quivering touch of white draws the inner edge of the mandible

Original Text: FOR BELIEVE ME THE FINAL PHILOSOPHY OF ART CAN ONLY RATIFY THEIR OPINION THAT THE BEAUTY OF A COCK ROBIN IS TO BE RED AND OF A GRASS PLOT TO BE GREEN AND THE BEST SKILL OF ART IS IN INSTANTLY SEIZING ON THE MANIFOLD DELICIOUSNESS OF LIGHT WHICH YOU CAN ONLY SEIZE BY PRECISION OF INSTANTANEOUS TOUCH
Transcribed Text: for believe me the final philosophy of art can only ratify their opinion that the beauty of a cock-robin is to be red and of a grass-plot to be green  and the best skill of art is in instantly seizing on the manifold deliciousness of light which you can only seize by precision of instantaneous touch

Original Text: NOW YOU WILL SEE IN THESE STUDIES THAT THE MOMENT THE WHITE IS INCLOSED PROPERLY AND HARMONIZED WITH THE OTHER HUES IT BECOMES SOMEHOW MORE PRECIOUS AND PEARLY THAN THE WHITE PAPER AND THAT I AM NOT AFRAID TO LEAVE A WHOLE FIELD OF UNTREATED WHITE PAPER ALL ROUND IT BEING SURE THAT EVEN THE LITTLE DIAMONDS IN THE ROUND WINDOW WILL TELL AS JEWELS IF THEY ARE GRADATED JUSTLY
Transcribed Text: now you will see in these studies that the moment the white is enclosed properly and harmonized with the other hues it becomes somehow more precious and pearly than the white paper  and that i am not afraid to leave a whole field of untreated white paper all round it being sure that even the little diamonds in the round window will tell as jewels if they are gradated justly

Original Text: BUT IN THIS VIGNETTE COPIED FROM TURNER YOU HAVE THE TWO PRINCIPLES BROUGHT OUT PERFECTLY
Transcribed Text: But in this vignette, copied from Turner, you have the two principles brought out perfectly.

Original Text: THEY ARE BEYOND ALL OTHER WORKS THAT I KNOW EXISTING DEPENDENT FOR THEIR EFFECT ON LOW SUBDUED TONES THEIR FAVORITE CHOICE IN TIME OF DAY BEING EITHER DAWN OR TWILIGHT AND EVEN THEIR BRIGHTEST SUNSETS PRODUCED CHIEFLY OUT OF GRAY PAPER
Transcribed Text: they are beyond all other works that i know existing dependent for their effect on low subdued tones their favorite choice in time of day being either dawn or twilight and even their brightest sunsets produced chiefly out of gray paper

Original Text: IT MAY BE THAT A GREAT COLORIST WILL USE HIS UTMOST FORCE OF COLOR AS A SINGER HIS FULL POWER OF VOICE BUT LOUD OR LOW THE VIRTUE IS IN BOTH CASES ALWAYS IN REFINEMENT NEVER IN LOUDNESS
Transcribed Text: it may be that a great colorist will use his utmost force of color as a singer his full power of voice but loud or low the virtue is in both cases always in refinement never in loudness

Original Text: IT MUST REMEMBER BE ONE OR THE OTHER
Transcribed Text: It must, remember, be one or the other.

Original Text: DO NOT THEREFORE THINK THAT THE GOTHIC SCHOOL IS AN EASY ONE
Transcribed Text: Do not, therefore, think that the Gothic school is an easy one.

Original Text: THE LAW OF THAT SCHOOL IS THAT EVERYTHING SHALL BE SEEN CLEARLY OR AT LEAST ONLY IN SUCH MIST OR FAINTNESS AS SHALL BE DELIGHTFUL AND I HAVE NO DOUBT THAT THE BEST INTRODUCTION TO IT WOULD BE THE ELEMENTARY PRACTICE OF PAINTING EVERY STUDY ON A GOLDEN GROUND
Transcribed Text: the law of that school is that everything shall be seen clearly or at least only in such mist or faintness as shall be delightful and i have no doubt that the best introduction to it would be the elementary practice of painting every study on a golden ground

Original Text: THIS AT ONCE COMPELS YOU TO UNDERSTAND THAT THE WORK IS TO BE IMAGINATIVE AND DECORATIVE THAT IT REPRESENTS BEAUTIFUL THINGS IN THE CLEAREST WAY BUT NOT UNDER EXISTING CONDITIONS AND THAT IN FACT YOU ARE PRODUCING JEWELER'S WORK RATHER THAN PICTURES
Transcribed Text: this at once compels you to understand that the work is to be imaginative and decorative that it represents beautiful things in the clearest way but not under existing conditions and that in fact you are producing jeweller's work rather than pictures

Original Text: THAT A STYLE IS RESTRAINED OR SEVERE DOES NOT MEAN THAT IT IS ALSO ERRONEOUS
Transcribed Text: That a style is restrained or severe does not mean that it is also erroneous.

Original Text: IN ALL EARLY GOTHIC ART INDEED YOU WILL FIND FAILURE OF THIS KIND ESPECIALLY DISTORTION AND RIGIDITY WHICH ARE IN MANY RESPECTS PAINFULLY TO BE COMPARED WITH THE SPLENDID REPOSE OF CLASSIC ART
Transcribed Text: in all early gothic art indeed you will find failure of this kind especially distortion and rigidity which are in many respects painfully to be compared with the splendid repose of classic art

Original Text: THE LARGE LETTER CONTAINS INDEED ENTIRELY FEEBLE AND ILL DRAWN FIGURES THAT IS MERELY CHILDISH AND FAILING WORK OF AN INFERIOR HAND IT IS NOT CHARACTERISTIC OF GOTHIC OR ANY OTHER SCHOOL
Transcribed Text: the large letter contains indeed entirely feeble and ill-drawn figures that is merely childish and failing work of an inferior hand it is not characteristic of gothic or any other school

Original Text: BUT OBSERVE YOU CAN ONLY DO THIS ON ONE CONDITION THAT OF STRIVING ALSO TO CREATE IN REALITY THE BEAUTY WHICH YOU SEEK IN IMAGINATION
Transcribed Text: but observe you can only do this on one condition that of striving also to create in reality the beauty which you seek in imagination

Original Text: IT WILL BE WHOLLY IMPOSSIBLE FOR YOU TO RETAIN THE TRANQUILLITY OF TEMPER AND FELICITY OF FAITH NECESSARY FOR NOBLE PURIST PAINTING UNLESS YOU ARE ACTIVELY ENGAGED IN PROMOTING THE FELICITY AND PEACE OF PRACTICAL LIFE
Transcribed Text: it will be wholly impossible for you to retain the tranquillity of temper and felicity of faith necessary for noble purist painting unless you are actively engaged in promoting the felicity and peace of practical life

Original Text: YOU MUST LOOK AT HIM IN THE FACE FIGHT HIM CONQUER HIM WITH WHAT SCATHE YOU MAY YOU NEED NOT THINK TO KEEP OUT OF THE WAY OF HIM
Transcribed Text: you must look at him in the face fight him conquer him with what scathe you may you need not think to keep out of the way of him

Original Text: THE COLORIST SAYS FIRST OF ALL AS MY DELICIOUS PAROQUET WAS RUBY SO THIS NASTY VIPER SHALL BE BLACK AND THEN IS THE QUESTION CAN I ROUND HIM OFF EVEN THOUGH HE IS BLACK AND MAKE HIM SLIMY AND YET SPRINGY AND CLOSE DOWN CLOTTED LIKE A POOL OF BLACK BLOOD ON THE EARTH ALL THE SAME
Transcribed Text: the colorist says first of all as my delicious parquet was ruby so this nasty viper shall be black and then is the question can i round him off even though he is black and make him slimy and yet springy and close down clotted like a pool of black blood on the earth all the same

Original Text: NOTHING WILL BE MORE PRECIOUS TO YOU I THINK IN THE PRACTICAL STUDY OF ART THAN THE CONVICTION WHICH WILL FORCE ITSELF ON YOU MORE AND MORE EVERY HOUR OF THE WAY ALL THINGS ARE BOUND TOGETHER LITTLE AND GREAT IN SPIRIT AND IN MATTER
Transcribed Text: nothing will be more precious to you i think in the practical study of art than the conviction which will force itself on you more and more every hour of the way all things are bound together little and great in spirit and in matter

Original Text: YOU KNOW I HAVE JUST BEEN TELLING YOU HOW THIS SCHOOL OF MATERIALISM AND CLAY INVOLVED ITSELF AT LAST IN CLOUD AND FIRE
Transcribed Text: You know I've just been telling you how this school of materialism and clay involved itself at last in cloud and fire.

Original Text: HERE IS AN EQUALLY TYPICAL GREEK SCHOOL LANDSCAPE BY WILSON LOST WHOLLY IN GOLDEN MIST THE TREES SO SLIGHTLY DRAWN THAT YOU DON'T KNOW IF THEY ARE TREES OR TOWERS AND NO CARE FOR COLOR WHATEVER PERFECTLY DECEPTIVE AND MARVELOUS EFFECT OF SUNSHINE THROUGH THE MIST APOLLO AND THE PYTHON
Transcribed Text: Here is an equally typical Greek school landscape by Wilson, lost wholly in golden mist, the trees so slightly drawn that you don't know if they are trees or towers, and no care for color whatsoever.  Perfectly deceptive and marvelous effect of sunshine through the mist, Apollo and the Python.

Original Text: NOW HERE IS RAPHAEL EXACTLY BETWEEN THE TWO TREES STILL DRAWN LEAF BY LEAF WHOLLY FORMAL BUT BEAUTIFUL MIST COMING GRADUALLY INTO THE DISTANCE
Transcribed Text: now here is raphael exactly between the two trees still drawn leaf by leaf wholly formal but beautiful mist coming gradually into the distance

Original Text: WELL THEN LAST HERE IS TURNER'S GREEK SCHOOL OF THE HIGHEST CLASS AND YOU DEFINE HIS ART ABSOLUTELY AS FIRST THE DISPLAYING INTENSELY AND WITH THE STERNEST INTELLECT OF NATURAL FORM AS IT IS AND THEN THE ENVELOPMENT OF IT WITH CLOUD AND FIRE
Transcribed Text: Well then, last, here is Turner's, Greek school of the highest class, and you define his art absolutely as first the displaying intensely and with the sternest intellect of natural form as it is, and then the envelopment of it with cloud and fire.

Original Text: ONLY THERE ARE TWO SORTS OF CLOUD AND FIRE
Transcribed Text: Only, there are two sorts of cloud and fire.

Original Text: HE KNOWS THEM BOTH
Transcribed Text: He knows them both.

Original Text: THERE'S ONE AND THERE'S ANOTHER THE DUDLEY AND THE FLINT
Transcribed Text: There's one and there's another, the Dudley and the Flint.

Original Text: IT IS ONLY A PENCIL OUTLINE BY EDWARD BURNE JONES IN ILLUSTRATION OF THE STORY OF PSYCHE IT IS THE INTRODUCTION OF PSYCHE AFTER ALL HER TROUBLES INTO HEAVEN
Transcribed Text: it is only a pencil outline by edward burne jones an illustration of the story of psyche it is the introduction of psyche after all her troubles into heaven

Original Text: EVERY PLANT IN THE GRASS IS SET FORMALLY GROWS PERFECTLY AND MAY BE REALIZED COMPLETELY
Transcribed Text: Every plant in the grass is set formally, grows perfectly, and may be realized completely.

Original Text: EXQUISITE ORDER AND UNIVERSAL WITH ETERNAL LIFE AND LIGHT THIS IS THE FAITH AND EFFORT OF THE SCHOOLS OF CRYSTAL AND YOU MAY DESCRIBE AND COMPLETE THEIR WORK QUITE LITERALLY BY TAKING ANY VERSES OF CHAUCER IN HIS TENDER MOOD AND OBSERVING HOW HE INSISTS ON THE CLEARNESS AND BRIGHTNESS FIRST AND THEN ON THE ORDER
Transcribed Text: exquisite order and universal with eternal life and light this is the faith and effort of the schools of crystal and you may describe and complete their work quite literally by taking any verses of chaucer in his tender mood  in observing how he insists on the clearness and brightness first and then on the order

Original Text: THUS IN CHAUCER'S DREAM
Transcribed Text: Thus, in Chaucer's dream,

Original Text: Overal Average
